annevk: So, to clarify: The tests you found failing in Firefox but succeeding in Safari & WebKit were (a) missing padding and (b) base64url decoding works. The case (a) seems to be in WPT; but looks like (b) is not even tested in wpt?
content.formatted_body: annevk: So, to clarify: The tests you found failing in Firefox but succeeding in Safari & WebKit were (a) missing padding and (b) base64url decoding works. The case (a) seems to be in WPT; but looks like (b) is not even tested in wpt?

content.body: aLoha
freddy: could be, it would also be interesting to test base64 that has whitespace and whether implementations strip it or not (as they do for data: URLs and atob/btoa)
content.formatted_body: freddy: could be, it would also be interesting to test base64 that has whitespace and whether implementations strip it or not (as they do for data: URLs and atob/btoa)

content.body: Austin Keener: Chrome and Firefox are buggy, Safari does this correctly; hopefully it'll get addressed as part of Interop 2023
content.formatted_body: Austin Keener: Chrome and Firefox are buggy, Safari does this correctly; hopefully it'll get addressed as part of Interop 2023

content.body: Script files with whitespace or integrity metadata with whitespace?
freddy: something like sha256-base64withtab\tandspaces init
content.formatted_body: freddy: something like sha256-base64withtab\tandspaces init

content.body: freddy: hmm, I guess that naturally ends up failing due to how integrity is parsed
content.formatted_body: freddy: hmm, I guess that naturally ends up failing due to how integrity is parsed

content.body: well, we split multiple items of integrity metadata on spaces, so not sure if that's even expected to work
freddy: so maybe that cannot be tested
content.formatted_body: freddy: so maybe that cannot be tested

content.body: yup
freddy: and I guess "spaces" there is HTML/Infra's definition of ASCII whitespace?
content.formatted_body: freddy: and I guess "spaces" there is HTML/Infra's definition of ASCII whitespace?

content.body: freddy: could still test \v then, but that's about it
content.formatted_body: freddy: could still test \v then, but that's about it

content.body: With the "missing padding" and base64url already working in other browsers, it seems unlikely that we can deprecate in Safari and Chrome. I consider just filing a bug for Firefox to support it
freddy: I kinda wish we could remove missing padding from base64 "default"
content.formatted_body: freddy: I kinda wish we could remove missing padding from base64 "default"

content.body: Do you want to drive a deprecation in Safari and Chrome?
Even forgiving base64 is stricter on padding than that
I want fewer base64 decoding options, yes; I'm not personally signing up for Chromium work
Well, how bad do you want them?
Especially with the test case for "missing padding" passing since forever in wpt, I don't see anyone care if Safari and Firefox were to stop supporting it
freddy: there's not just that problem right, it also needs to be specified
content.formatted_body: freddy: there's not just that problem right, it also needs to be specified

content.body: so, "base64 decoding with padding ignored" is a new thing in terms of standards infra?
freddy: I could totally see this getting fixed as part of some interior effort, esp as base64 encoders will add padding so I doubt this is a problem in practice
content.formatted_body: freddy: I could totally see this getting fixed as part of some interior effort, esp as base64 encoders will add padding so I doubt this is a problem in practice

content.body: freddy: yes
content.formatted_body: freddy: yes

content.body: But is it also a new thing in terms of how browsers implements decoding across other features?
* But is it also a new thing in terms of how browsers implement decoding across other features?

m.new_content.body: But is it also a new thing in terms of how browsers implement decoding across other features?

content.body: freddy: I'm not currently aware of features besides CSP/SRI
content.formatted_body: freddy: I'm not currently aware of features besides CSP/SRI

content.body: freddy: though there are some code paths that have used it due to lack of care
content.formatted_body: freddy: though there are some code paths that have used it due to lack of care

content.body: Firefox does not seem to have an "ignore padding" setting in the existing base64decoder but  there is a setting for the base64urldecoder
freddy: for base64url WebKit never is strict on padding, but I believe that is somewhat expected for base64url even though that could have sec consequences as well
content.formatted_body: freddy: for base64url WebKit never is strict on padding, but I believe that is somewhat expected for base64url even though that could have sec consequences as well

content.body: well "never" except that one integrity test case
freddy: that's a base64 failure, not a base64url one
content.formatted_body: freddy: that's a base64 failure, not a base64url one

content.body: I think for now I'll update that patch to have 4 encoding modes, DefaultWithoutStrictPadding, DefaultWithStrictPadding, DefaultWithStrictPaddingAndIgnoreWhiteSpace, and URL (equivalent to DefaultWithoutStrictPadding except for the map used); that's what WebKit has today minus a mode for treating \v as whitespace, which was just a bug due to have C defines ASCII whitespace
content.formatted_body: I think for now I'll update that patch to have 4 encoding modes, DefaultWithoutStrictPadding, DefaultWithStrictPadding, DefaultWithStrictPaddingAndIgnoreWhiteSpace, and URL (equivalent to DefaultWithoutStrictPadding except for the map used); that's what WebKit has today minus a mode for treating \v as whitespace, which was just a bug due to have C defines ASCII whitespace

content.body: I somewhat hope that DefaultWithoutStrictPadding can be removed and some investigation is needed whether we should have URLWithStrictPadding
And I need to look into whether "StrictPadding" is accurate enough of a term as data: URLs and the like aren't super strict on it either (but they do have some checks at least)
What happened to the Trusted Types spec?
nevermind, I guess the URL just changed
â€¦or else I had it wrong to begin with
freddy: what would be even better btw is if we could make CSP/SRI rely on base64 *en*coding exclusively; that would be even stricter, but also a lot cleaner for security-sensitive stuff
content.formatted_body: freddy: what would be even better btw is if we could make CSP/SRI rely on base64 encoding exclusively; that would be even stricter, but also a lot cleaner for security-sensitive stuff
